channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-8063] Filter HFiles based on first/last key
item.description:
1. hbase-5010 introduced a filter mechanism based on timerange hint
  2. this jira is a placeholder just for keyrange hint: currently, low layer(hfile reader) has first/last key getter methods already. we should utilize this information to pre-filte hfiles while choosing scanners from storefiles.

It's just a raw thought right now, no patch available yet. I'll summit a patch asap if it's reasonable, welcome to give some suggestions/comments
item.summary: Filter HFiles based on first/last key

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: I think bloomfilter + lazyseek can filter the storefiles the case you point, is it so ?
good point. but per my understanding, seems bloomfilter&lazyseek could not work on non-get scan + bloomtype != rowcol, please correct me if it's wrong

could not work on non-get scan + bloomtype != rowcol

you are right, so we can filter the hfile if its first key >= scan's stop key or its lastkey <= scan's start key
thanks for confirming
let's see QA robot

Looks like there is compilation error:
https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/4755/console

In passesKeyRangeFilter():


+      boolean nonOverLapping = (Bytes.compareTo(this.getFirstRowKey(), scan.getStopRow()) > 0

'>' should be '>=' because:


   * @param stopRow row to stop scanner before (exclusive)

+      if (Bytes.equals(scan.getStartRow(), HConstants.EMPTY_START_ROW)

+      boolean nonOverLapping = (Bytes.compareTo(this.getFirstRowKey(), scan.getStopRow()) > 0

We should use StoreFile#Reader#getComparator() instead of Bytes.equals or Bytes.compareTo
Ted Yu, if you change ">" to ">=", then you have to write some codes to handle/verify "get" case, which startRow == stopRow, making this function redundant. i thought the original is just fine.

chunhui shen, the StoreFile#Reader#getComparator() probably is a KeyComparator instance(Please correct me if wrong), and in this function, we just want to compare the raw byte array, so it should be fine with Bytes.compareTo

You could get the reason from HRegionInfo#getComparator() why we shouldn't use Bytes.compareTo directly.

If we use Bytes.compareTo, I think we would may make mistake for META table

O, seems there's a trouble here, my two thoughts

  1. generate keyvalue instances per scan.start/stopRow(seems current KeyValue class doesn't have any methods like createKeyValueFromRow,right?), then compare with getFirstKey/getLastKey, maybe we need to handle some details,e.g. kv's timestamp, type? it's error-prone for me at least
  2. shortcut MetaKeyComparator scenario, just return true if it's a MetaKeyComparator instance. since our original idea is to optimize normal user hfile, not internal system hfile, it should be ok. I prefer to this choice.
    chunhui shen, how about you?
addressed compile error

http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12573246/HBASE-8063-v2.txt
against trunk revision .

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 3 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

-1 site. The patch appears to cause mvn site goal to fail.

I am prefered to the first choice,

using KeyValue#createFirstOnRow and KeyValue#createLastOnRow to create KeyValue per startRow/stopRow


+    assertEquals(accessedFiles.size(), expectedCount);

Changed to assertEquals(expectedCount,accessedFiles.size());
changed per chunhui's comments

Patch v3 is clean.


+    for (Object type : TYPE_COUNT.keySet()) {

+        params.add(new Object[] { type, TYPE_COUNT.get(type) });

Indentation should use two spaces.

In testScannerSelection(), looks like htd is not closed.

after fixing the above format problem,
patch is good to me

In testScannerSelection(), looks like htd is not closed.

How to close HTableDescriptor? I am also unknown...
The latest v4 patch should address the above style problem
